title: 111_hr3694
content: The Act may be cited as the "Removing Excess Litigation Involving Energy on Federal Lands Act" or the "RELIEF Act". Congress finds that the US spends over $1 billion daily on importing crude oil, the largest wealth transfer in history. The US has vast oil and natural gas reserves in the outer Continental Shelf. Environmental groups legally challenge leases, delaying energy resources reaching the public at a high cost to the economy. Congress finds that legal challenges delay energy resources from reaching the American public at a high cost to the economy, necessitating expedited judicial review to prevent abuse of the judicial system. Exclusive jurisdiction over causes and claims related to covered energy projects is granted to the United States District Court for the District of Columbia. All causes and claims must be filed within 60 days of the action or decision by a Federal official, or they will be barred. SEC. 5. District Court for the District of Columbia must resolve all proceedings subject to section 3 within 180 days, taking precedence over other matters. Failure to comply results in dismissal with prejudice. SEC. 6. Only the Supreme Court can review judgments from the district court. SEC. 7. Deadline for appeal to the Supreme Court. SEC. 6 states that only the Supreme Court can review judgments from the district court. SEC. 7 sets a deadline for appeals to the Supreme Court, ensuring expedited resolution within 180 days. SEC. 8 limits the scope of review and relief. SEC. 8 limits the scope of review and relief in judicial review of Federal actions under the Act, presuming administrative findings correct unless proven otherwise by clear evidence. Prospective relief can only be granted if narrowly drawn and least intrusive. SEC. 9 of the Act addresses legal fees for judicial review petitions, requiring non-prevailing parties to pay fees to prevailing parties unless special circumstances apply. SEC. 10 excludes disputes over lease obligations from the Act's scope, while SEC. 11 defines a covered energy project. SEC. 10 excludes disputes over lease obligations from the Act's scope, while SEC. 11 defines a covered energy project as actions or decisions related to leasing Federal lands for energy exploration and production.
